action.action-desc: Mr. Nunn of Iowa (for himself and Mr. Riley of New York) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To amend title 18, United States Code, to establish criminal penalties for the reckless importation or handling of dangerous agricultural pathogens.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Preventing Lethal Agricultural and National Threats (PLANT) Act.

section.header: Reckless importation of dangerous agricultural pathogens
section.text: Title 18 U.S.C. is amended by inserting after section 175b the following:

section.header: Reckless importation of dangerous agricultural pathogens.

subsection.text: Whoever knowingly or recklessly imports a biological agent, toxin, or organismâ€”

paragraph.text: without the required permit or authorization from the U.S. Department of Agriculture or other appropriate agency; and
where such agent, toxin, or organism is designated by regulation as a high-risk agricultural pathogen capable of causing significant harm to U.S. crops, livestock, or agricultural ecosystems,

subsection.continuation-text: Shall be fined under this title or imprisoned not more than 10 years, or both.

paragraph.text: is committed by a person acting on behalf of, or funded by, a foreign government; or
results in actual economic damage exceeding $1,000,000;

subsection.continuation-text: Then the term of imprisonment may be up to 20 years.

paragraph.text: the term recklessly means the person consciously disregarded a substantial and unjustifiable risk that the pathogen could cause significant harm.
the term high-risk agricultural pathogen shall be defined by the Secretary of Agriculture and published via regulation.
